info.game_comments:
1988 Senior Tournament semifinal game 1.
Missing first 8 clues.

(2, 1).clue: Dir. of Indiana U.'s Institute for Sexual Research, his reports were 1st widely known surveys of sexual behavior

(5, 1).clue: As of December 4, 1981, the CIA was given permission to "spy" within this country

(1, 2).clue: Boticelli is famous for painting "The Birth of" this goddess

(2, 2).clue: This "Today" show hostess was once described as "a cornfield Catherine Deneuve"

(3, 2).clue: Heloise says after this wrap has been used, it can be reused as a pot & pan scrubber

(4, 2).clue: He composed the music for The Honeymooners' theme

(5, 2).clue: Some credit Francis Bacon with coining this term for an agent who burrows into a rival spy agency

(2, 3).clue: (AUDIO DAILY DOUBLE) Born in Peru, Indiana, the composer of the following was known for his urbane style: "I've got you under my skin / I've got you..."

(3, 3).clue: In 1918, Charles Strite was 1st to put a timer on this type of breakfast appliance

(4, 3).clue: While Art Carney is not paid for today's reruns, this actress asked for & gets "residuals in perpetuity"

(5, 3).clue: Warned by spies, Francis Drake spent time bowling while waiting for invasion by this in 1588

(2, 4).clue: The original "Mr. Belvedere", this native Hoosier was once the leading ballroom dancer in NYC

(3, 4).clue: To counteract pungent cooking smells, Heloise says slowly heat a tsp. or 2 of this bark spice in some water

(5, 4).clue: It's now thought she was innocent, but shot by the French as a military coverup

(1, 5).clue: All of the artists mentioned above created their works during the period known as this

(2, 5).clue: Whether "The frost is on the punkin" or not, he's widely known as the "Hoosier Poet"

(3, 5).clue: Used as a thickener, agar-agar is a product derived from this aquatic plant

(5, 5).clue: It's said this Macedonian read the letters his men sent home, thus discovering & eliminating the disloyal ones

(1, 1).clue: In the coinage system proposed by Jefferson, this metal was chosen for the coin worth 1/10 of a dollar

(2, 1).clue: It's the color most frequently associated with environmentalists

(3, 1).clue: The Red Sea had a good part in this film

(4, 1).clue: Ency. Americana says Burma was probably devastated more than any other nation during this war

(1, 2).clue: Members of this 19th century political party answered any question on policy with "I don't know"

(2, 2).clue: Part of this vital layer protecting Earth from ultraviolet rays disappeared over Antarctica in 1986

(3, 2).clue: Nursery rhyme title of 2 remakes of the Agatha Christie classic "And Then There Were None"

(4, 2).clue: In 1919, peaceful protests against Japanese rule in this peninsular country were violently crushed

(5, 2).clue: Ruth, Marion, Nancy, Micheline, Karen, Sandra, Nina & Liz were this lyricist's 8 "fair ladies"

(6, 2).clue: How a rejected lover might waste away with yearning, especially under an evergreen

(1, 3).clue: In 1894, Congress passed a law making this graduated for the 1st time

(2, 3).clue: A conservation organization is named for this 1653 author of "The Compleat Angler"

(3, 3).clue: Classic western whose title could have been copied from an Arizona train schedule

(4, 3).clue: The average January temperature of Ulan Bator, capital of this country, is -17° F

(5, 3).clue: Author whose wives were Hadley Richardson, Pauline Pfeiffer, Martha Gellhorn & Mary Welsh

(6, 3).clue: Found on your face, it sounds like it's flicked in flagellation

(1, 4).clue: During the Chicago 8 trial, this judge ordered Bobby Seale bound & gagged

(2, 4).clue: In 1985, he began lobbying on the acid rain issue on behalf of the Canadian government

(3, 4).clue: This film featured almost a dozen classic TV sketches with Sid Caesar
(3, 4).correct response: Ten from Your Show of Shows

(4, 4).clue: This political group changed Cambodia's name to Kampuchea

(6, 4).clue: Between 1905 & 1917, this Russian legislative body was dissolved 4 times

(1, 5).clue: In 1682, this Frenchman claimed the entire Mississippi valley for the French

(3, 5).clue: From a John O'Hara novel, it's an address Gary Cooper got to know very well

(4, 5).clue: This early 20th c. president had served as 1st American civil governor of the Philippines

(0, 0).clue: The only people to have held this post are Shirley Hufstedler, Terrel Bell & Wm. J. Bennett
